Spark App

A collaborative storytelling app helping connect the Asian diaspora within Canada.

Capstone

UX Research

UI Design

Project Info

Project Type
Independent Capsone

Team
Solo

My Role
UX Designer
UI Designer

Timeline
6 months

Tools
Figma
Miro
Condens.io
Otter.io

Over a 6 month period between September 2020 to April 2021, I worked on this project as my capstone in my final year of Sheridan’s Interaction Design program. The inspiration came grew from conversations with Asian-Canadian friends and genuine, deep-seated curiosity.

Introduction

Immigration is hard.

Around 300 000 people uproot and immigrate to Canada each year, with the top three origins of foreign-born people being from India, China, and the Philippines.

Immigrants experience multiple layers of stress, also known as acculturation stress, which can significantly impact their mental and emotional well-being. This can result in a loss of cultural norms, social status, religious customs, social support systems, adjusting to a new culture and experiencing changes in identity.

Problem Statement

How might we help foster more positive cultural connections within 1st and 2nd gen Asian-Canadians?

Research & Findings

Speaking with 15 Asian-Canadians about their cultural transitions.

I conducted interviews with 15 1st and 2nd gen Asian-Canadians aged 18-31 with origins from the Philippines, China, India, Korea, Vietnam, and Pakistan. Many factors came into play when building connection, the most influential being their past experiences and their family’s transition into Canadian culture.

RESEARCH QUESTION
What challenges do Asian-Canadians face when connecting to their ethnic culture?

01
The influences of their two cultures frequently pull them in opposite directions causing internal pressure and conflict about their personal identity and social place

02
How well the participants spoke their parents' languages affected their personal identity greatly.

03
Those living in or who grew up in white-dominant populations felt a greater pressure to conform and repress their ethnic culture.

04
Connection to culture primarily depends on family’s influence which lessens over time.

05
Asian-Canadians desire to connect, but don’t know how or where to start.

Co-Creation Agenda

1. Life Map
Participants first mapped out their cultural journey on a timeline, adding significant life events, how they’ve connected or disconnected to their ethnic culture, and emotions.

Why
It was a highly reflective activity that gave context to their goals and motivations over time while also getting them in the mindset for co-creating.

2. Empathy Map
After thinking a lot about the past, this activity focused on their present.

Why
It was to help me better understand what goes on in their day-to-day and how their culture affects them.

3. Questionnaire
Next, they were to answer 3 questions to find out how they wanted to connect with their ethnic culture.

Why
This really clarified many assumptions I had surrounding the solution.

4. Crazy 8’s
Lastly, using the challenge statement participants were to think about all the activities they had just completed and try to come up with as many solutions to the challenge as possible.

Why
This activity helped generate more ideas from the target audience themselves, to help mitigate my personal biases towards solutions.

Storytelling Interview

I conducted 5 semi-structured storytelling interviews with pairs of siblings and cousins aged 17-25, with either individuals being a 1st or 2nd gen Asian-Canadian. The participant ethnic origins from the Philippines, China, Vietnam, Thailand, and Laos.

During the interviews, participants were asked to collaboratively tell a story of a favourite shared memory. This was for the purpose of observing how Asian-Canadian family members interact with each other when telling a story and uncover the underlying structure of stories.

“
Memories are hard to recall on the spot. An experience worth telling, must be funny or interesting.

Ideation

A better platform for sharing life experiences.

An app that allows friends and families to retell and recreate experiences in a collaborative space, helping them preserve their memories and traditions from anywhere in the world. It lets users find their cultural community, share stories, and provides people a place to learn about themselves and their culture.

Pros

  • There currently isn’t a collaborative creation platform just for Asian-Canadians
  • Encourages all perspectives and opinions
  • Allows ESL users to communicate easily with English speakers

Cons

  • Frustration could arise with older less tech-savvy users
  • Frustration could arise in the younger users having to teach their older family members how to use the app
